meta.description:
We have entered a sometimes-unconfortable weird duality where we want an extremely personalized experience everywhere but also tend to reject any prying attempts to learn patterns of ours.
It is now up to companies and institutions to invest in two complementary and necessary venues: transparency so that the person never feels they're being misled and privacy protection methods and structures.
Not every entity has the magnitude of Facebook to withstand the loss of trust and finantial hit breach after breach.

With the slew of machine learning and AI implementations to monitor behavior and find patterns in everything, the field of personalization has never been more fertile - and people will embrace it.
The crucial factor here is to find the right balance between customer data and driving convenience - customer loyalty will reside in the entity that can meet that one consumer's demands to a T.

Customer experience has a 24/7 frequency, nowadays. Through chat platforms such as Whatsapp or Instagram Direct, people can easily get in touch with anyone, anywhere, and they want instant answers to any query. �If you can take my money 24 hours a day, you should be available to answer my questions, too.�

While the sharing economy was mostly accelerated in mobility and real estate rental, its consequences are being felt universally. This is one of the big drivers in the rise of platform organizations.
The regular user is - of course - relatively agnostic to how a service operates. The consensual shift to platforms supported by sharing economy models is explained by the sheer scalability and seamlessness that are now within reach.
To businesses operating with their core parallel to these players, it is urgent that they form partnerships, because the advantages in speed, efficiency and ease of maintenance/cost to run seem unrivalled and piling up.

Part of a greater whole, transparency has never been as present in people's minds as today. Besides paying attention to the supply chain footprint of the food we buy, society is increasingly privileging options in every field that operate in a glassdoor manner. Clothes coming from Southeast Asia resonate with humans rights violations. Users are glad to know that Apple is promising to use 100% recycled Aluminum and stride to recycle 100% in their own and (already billions) other iPhones sold.

Technology adoption among is universally attributed to Millenials and younger generations. This is partly true, but leads to a gross underestimation of tech use in older generations. Especially older urban dwellers are more than happy to adopt smart locks for safety, kitchen assistants for convenient cooking and uber to stop waiting for a taxi while it's raining.
This proves to be a greatly misrepresented segment that embodies a great business oportunity, if only companies start planning around it (remember older generations also have greater purchasing power).

There�s an increasing saturation over the massification of artificially fabricated lifestyles projected by TV, Facebook, and Instagram accounts. People are craving for authenticity and real-human connections.

Having an active interest in one's health. Be health consciousness implies to know what good health is and what are healthy and unhealthy practices; to monitor health condition like body weight, sleep control, sight and hearing test, mental checkups; to avoid practices that adversely affect one�s health; to take corrective actions whenever your health is not within acceptable norms.

Technology has finally matured enough for customers to start trusting it to avoid some of the most inefficient parts of their shopping experience. Machine learning is helping people to complete their shopping list while artificial vision is enabling the skipping of those never-ending checkout lines. Many other applications are being implemented to optimize people�s time and maximize their life quality.

The massification of online courses reflects the increasing effort that is needed nowadays to keep up with technology advancements. Knowledge is more accessible then ever, but also more volatile. Learning is a continuous process and people are looking for the right tools to keep on board of the train to the future.

Collected from renewable sources such as sunlight, wind, rain, tides, waves and geothermal heat, renewable energy is charging the future. �It is expected that by 2040 the production of renewable electricity will be able to guarantee, in a cost-effective way, the total annual electricity consumption of mainland Portugal� advanced the Portuguese Renewable Energy Association as in March 2018, renewable energy generated 104% of Portugal�s electricity consumption. According to the same source, this successful event demonstrated that �renewable energy can be relied upon as a secure and viable source with which to completely meet the country�s electricity demands�. Some of the biggest companies in the world, including Apple, Facebook, Google, and Microsoft, are massively buying renewable energy and, consequently, reshaping the entire supply chain. �The IT sector has been responsible for more than 7GW of new renewable energy globally � enough to power 5m homes� says Gary Cook, Greenpeace�s senior corporate campaigner.

Without touching the discussion topic to what caused this movement, it is unquestionably that there is a fast-rising concern for how "gut-friendly" the food we buy really is. Fashionable expressions such as pro or prebiotics are dealbreakers in the daily choices made by a growingly significant segment of society. To the unaware, the myriad of intolerances we hear about seems to have sprung from nowhere, but it certainly drove an unforeseen demand for the likes of tempeh, kefir, kimchi, flaxseed, and anything else that helps the consumer to steer clear from the wide selection of ingredients they've found harmful (think gluten, sat, unsat or trans fat, lactose, etc...).

Less than a quarter of the food that is wasted in the US, UK and Europe could feed the one billion hungry people all around the world. With an estimation of 1.3 billion tonnes of food being wasted every year, people are looking for this topic with particular concern and expect the companies where they spend their money to tackle this issue.

Total foreign residency in Portugal has been steadily rising for a few years, to a point where a significant demographic segment has different primary languages and cultures. If the current political climate remains relatively stable, this is only expected to accelerate.
With today's advances in personalization, behavior analysis and related tools, great oportunities lie in adjusting supply to a changing customer base.

Today's means of acquiring knowledge in any topic is widely different from a few years ago. Content creation in the web today has reached a granularity that allows for whomever, with whichever skillbase to quickly find informative content from the most practical topics such as "How to: fry, bake, poach and scramble eggs" to the most complex and abstract subjects in Advanced Mathematics or Quantum Mechanics.
While true volume exists mostly in english, with instant contextual translation making strides, it is all quickly being democratized to all.
This trend is being felt at the corporate level too, with Google, Apple and other powerhouses announcing that academic degrees are no longer weighted the way they were.
Companies should much rather employ someone who can quickly and effectively learn skill X when current standard Y turns obsolete than a proven expert in Y.

People will compare players, even from different industries, using the same criteria. Customers are indifferent to cost structure: if a store offers free bags, they'll expect the same treat from every other store. To stay competitive, companies should be able to optimize their cost structure and establish what's essential to provide what the customers are expecting. To do so, they must understand that people's expectations can come from the least expectable places.

names: Fluid Expectations in Placemaking: Four Trends and Strategies

meta.description: It is no secret that the portuguese demographic pyramid is getting dangerously top-heavy. What may be changing, at least in the professional market, is what companies can use to face this threat. Companies should brace for a powerful hit in the form of retirement benefits and healthcare as baby boomers maintain leadership and it simultaneously becomes harder to attract (and maintain) young talent. The uberization of every field is one way this is being tackled (or rather, circumvented), but awareness (and investment along with it) needs to increase for companies to find creative ways of facing this looming threat.

Over the last few years, society has embraced connected devices and progressively divorced traditional linear content services. Over-the-top (OTT) video from players such as Netflix, Amazon Fire TV, Apple TV or Roku had a delayed start in the Portuguese market, as is usual, but this makes it all the more relevant for side business to rethink their content design and marketing. Advertisers today have a blank canvas full of opportunities to connect with consumers in a previously impossibly organic, personalized manner.

According to ConvenienceStore, �the increase in shoppers looking for meals �for the next three days� is growing with 55% of shoppers claiming to visit a convenience store for a top-up mission, 11% for a meal prep mission and 17% for food-to-go�.
As the shopping experience keeps getting more convenient, people tend to privilege smaller baskets and increase the frequency of their visits to the store. Retailers are accompanying this trend by reducing store�s dimensions, while optimizing their cost per square meter.

A social trend that has closely followed the technological advances in interfacing, it is shifting the paradigm of how we connect with machines. There is a reason babies today can outperform their parents on a tablet at the age of 2 (imagine doing that with MS-DOS in the 80s) and there will also be consequences.
For one, there will be zero tolerance for unintuitive UI, users will simply move to one of your 100 competitors for a better experience. We need to build for any human to use, with bonus points if the interface is adaptive to the individual user.

names:
Intelligent interfaces -
Reimagining the way humans

meta.description: Reviews, good pictures and nice displays are not enough anymore. The biggest friction in eCommerce is the fact that, before buying a product, people still want to feel its touch, taste or smell. And whoever's capable of providing that will get the upper hand over those who can't.

According to BBC, 400 million tons of plastic is produced every year with 40% of its applications being thrown out after the first use. Plastic is not biodegradable, which means it will stay around for hundreds of years � representing a big threat for the environment. 
The debate on reducing plastic production is gathering more followers every day and people expect retailers to be a part of the process to save the world. Sustainable materials for packaging and bulk food are some of the solutions that customers value and are willing to pay extra to get.

Consumers are shifting their attention from TV to Youtube, Facebook and Instagram. Social media influencers are the new epicenter of new lifestyles, behaviors and social trends. This represents an opportunity for retailers to promote their products in a more decentralized (and effective) way. Companies who provide digital sharable products and experiences increase their reach with continuously growing scalability.

A single family will probably have numerous diet restrictions: grandma is lactose intolerant, the father is gluten--free and the older daughter is trying a vegan regimen. The criteria of this family�s shopping list is almost impossible to meet � and that�s why they�ll prefer the retailer who provides them a customized service that addresses all their needs. By reducing the amount of plastic needed for packaging, bulk food is a win-win situation to the customer, the retailer, and the planet.

Consumers want to know the story of the product. A study conducted by Origin/Hill Holiday found that people are willing to pay more for a product that's accompanied by a narrative - its perceived value will increase if it's followed by the producer�s story, another user's review or any other type of content that helps people relating to that particular item or service.

Consumer's attention span has been abruptly decreasing for the past few years. If a brand can't communicate its messages or value propositions in the first seconds of the conversation, people will look for something else. Customers expect to be immediately served and will have no mercy for the runner up in the delivery race. Whoever's serves first, serves better.

FOMO defines the fear of not getting in on a deal, experience, event or other activity, strongly correlated with social pressure. It is not exactly recent/emergent, but is today increasingly relevant, and is most prevalent among millenials and younger generations, in/entering prime spending age.
Marketing tends to overuse this concept to motivate consumers to do last-minute purchasing decisions. This has to be done with care, as it risks frustrating loyal customers who will then be tired of having their hand forced.
The number of offices with a desk rotation policy is increasing everywhere. Workers are valuing the convenience that flexible work stations represent, as well as the freedom to work from home.

Too much choice can be as harmful as no choice at all: just think of the time you spend trying to choose what to watch on Netflix. AI and Data mining are helping customers making some sense of the chaos with shopping list recommendations or customized campaigns.

Schizophrenic (or non-linear) consumption portrays the fact that some consumers are willing to spend less money on some purchases so that they can dive into some other indulgences (e.g. exclusively buying white brand food to save for an iPhone). This behavior can be fostered by financial savviness or can simply be arbitrary.

The number of people with particular diets is increasing and food retailers must adapt. People want a customized service for every situation (e.g. 2 people in a couple buying 2 different meals and still eating together)
People, particularly millennials, are increasingly looking for careers with a purpose and avoiding jobs with meaningless repetitive tasks.
The fight against animal cruelty keeps gathering new supporters and some paradigms such as bullfighting and slaughterhouses may have their days counted.

Virtual assistants can provide quick information to customers, employees or partners on the go. These assistants can be available to remote users through smartphones, smart speakers, or smart appliances. Presential users can access these assistants through kiosks. Chatbots can provide quick information to customers, employees or partners on the go. Can be made available through dedicated messaging APPs like WhatsAPP or embedded in existing channels like the on-line stores or APPs.

Automatic ordering and checkout is the simplest embodiment of the A-commerce trend. The aim of this application is always to rid the customer journey of all friction at the checkout and ordering stages. Subconsciously, if companies already carry so much data on consumers, why should they ever have to ask for confirmation/details on an action they've performed tens, hundreds or even thousands of times.
I've bought the same toilet paper for 3 years in a row, can the multi-million euro retailer I shop at pick up on that?

Automated styling is the most organic practical hemisphere of automated commerce. This previously sci-fi reserved ambition, would in theory (not for long) curate a consumer's cart whenever they need an extra hand with choosing or simply aren't interested in spending time differentiating between two products. For some, shopping for a summer wardrobe is a ritual, for others a pain. Despite it all, with select products and services, a majority of people don't necessarily value time spent in choosing - think detergent, toilet paper, toothpaste. Wouldn't it be amazing to have the "just choose the cheapest one" or "get my anything whitening and minty".

While we can tackle the aging problem by leveraging complex engineering solutions, the human dimension remains. This sphere is often harder to approach due to its inherent abstractiveness and inertia for culture change. A well-oiled corporate environment in the future will necessarily nurture collaboration between senior and junior employees - optimizing knowledge transfer and better exploring the value of experience so commonly overlooked.
Making part-time or freelance job opportunities available to retirees to overcome scarcity of labour and allow them an extra income stream and a renewed sense of purpose.

Include in the assortment products that can be communicated as cruelty free. The sourcing of these product can be done by scouting producers that are already using cruelty free production approaches or by providing training to the producers of our club towards those approaches.
While brands develop communication to be inspiring and convince customers that they are guided by the correct values, different awareness campaigns may be created and supported.
Provide tools that deliver quick and relevant information for employees of customer care (call centres) to allow the written contact with several customers simultaneously.

With robots and automation making more and more frequent appearances in our everyday lives, we, people, are confronted with the progressive decrease in human interaction. Despite this, at our core, we are social animals, and we like being with other people (whether we like it or not, ah!). A collateral consequence that arises is that people give authenticity and humanity higher value. Federico Marchetti said it beautifully when he predicted that "in the future there will be one label that will convey [a sense quality] to the customers - 'Made by Humans'".
Making the right choices when it comes to automation isn't always limited to efficiency and cost. Allowing the human touch to permeate your products and services where it matters most, can be a powerful loyalty driver, justifying and even contradicting RPAs or seamlessness.
Develop and communicate a new range of products and services to help customers that want to stay more time offline to still get convenience, quality and attractive prices.

Interfacing is a hot topic nowadays. Depending on the industry, a platform's ease of use (or lack thereof) can overturn entire business ventures. It is unquestionable that we veer towards a future where human-machine interfaces are more organic, aiming to eradicate learning curves.
Currently, voice control is, with little doubt, the closest we have to achieving the fluidity necessary for this - we certainly must teach someone what "Ctrl+A" is, and does anything interesting, but shouting "Hey Siri, play me the Beatles" comes second to language (and some good taste...).

Another iteration in the new interface world, motion control is one that ambitions (arguably) the easiest learning processes. Motion for control is an obvious extension of our sensorial world. A trivial example is the simple but revolutionary "pinch-to-zoom" gesture popularised to omnipresence (and usually attributed to Apple's first iPhone).

People use their unique biological traits to be identified, manage access to resources or authorize payments through voice, fingerprint or iris recognition. After the biometric identification employees, partners and customers access admission-controlled assets (e.g. offices, technical areas, or lockers) or classified information (e.g. interaction with customer care, or APPs) without using codes or cards.

The awareness to the plastic residues problem is forcing some action into rethinking the end-of-life of products, namely their packages. A solution passes through refilling ou separating more thoroughly and sending back to producer in order to reuse packages.
Since omnichannel is a given right to the customer in several funcionalities, it is expected that bulk foods also reach the online basket.

Lives are changing, with easy access to different lifestyles people may not be dedicated to traditional activities anymore. This means that tasks like buying raw and cooking may be replaced for ordering in, having take-away food or eating out. By transforming supermarkets into food preparation locations we are creating an in-between of restaurants and home-cooking.

While Flexible Workplaces is an unquestionable trending success, there is always going to be a core mass of work that gravitates around physical headquarters. There is a parallel trend turning corporate headquarters into small cities. Whether it is one of the FAANG giants or an group of smaller companies, workers rejoice when finding all amenities within walking distance from work.
Forgot your allergy meds? Take a break and visit the pharmacy. Sick of traffic? Get up early and use that time in the work gym instead. Need to restock groceries? Walk by the supermarket when you get off.

The new technological revolution is drastically decreasing the average half-life of learned skills. Thus, it's of the utmost importance for companies and employees to adapt to the roulette of new scenarios by gathering as many tools as possible. Knowledge is quantic nowadays.
Organizing courses and workshops to help customers make the best choices and the best use of the products/services they buy.

Addressing the need to belong is the oldest commercial trick in the book. People want to be a part of something and brands must be able to address that social requirement. The good news is that the digital transformation that we're living in is boosting the businesses' ability to do it.

The digital age is skyrocketing the (peer) pressure through the roof, which, for retailers, represents both an opportunity (the feeling of emergency and the fear of missing out are sales drivers) and a threat (people's increasing desire to disconnect and to subscribe to digital detox programs or lifestyles).

Brands are living inside its customers' pockets 24/7. The ability for retailers to create the feeling of emergency is, therefore, higher than it ever was. 

People want to belong and to feel unique and businesses have an unprecedented opportunity to take advantage of those (apparently) paradoxical needs.

It's not just about flexible hours or hot desks anymore. Different employees have different needs and now more than ever, companies must be willing to listen and to accommodate as many requirements as possible.

Nowadays, "half the world away" is at a distance of a WIFI password. The ability to access information and to communicate from anywhere, at anytime, is reshaping the office paradigm and the way teams collaborate. The generation of global citizens is now paving the way to the new wave of global coworkers.
Offering spaces in store that invite and provide adequate conditions for customers to work and organize gatherings.
In a world that cannot support the current consumption of protein sources, alternatives are being developed to deliver the same taste, structure or nutritional value of what it intents to replace.
Newer generations understand that in order to have a future livable world, some changes in lifestyle have to be made, like reducing the consumption of meat to a more sustainable and healthy intake.

Coming partly as a response to consumers' loss of confidence in the corporate world, the glassbox model is the most honest and radical stance relative to transparency and accountability - the companies adopting this model tend to openly disclose company policy (e.g. hiring practices, salary) and veer towards open-source development. When faced with a complication that could turn into a scandal/outrage, these agents announce that fact along with efforts being made to correct the wrong, instead of trying to quietly resolve the matter before it is discovered.

Provide tools that ease the collection and reading of traceability information of food and non-food products. Adopting solutions and establishing partnerships that enable a supply-chain-wide traceability will help any company raise consumer trust as well as improving internal accountability.

Information by request is already a reality in a selection of fields. Food past and characteristics seem like a logical next step that may align with the crescendo of worries about the environment and a fairer world.

Minimalism and healthy trends give result to clean labels. This is a method to turn packages clearer and enlight customers of everything that is inside a package, so that people know exactly what they are consuming.
Living in a world of personalization means stop applying the one size fits all to everyone and that means accepting people in their differences in more serious environments.

People are valuing what are called superfoods and non-empty calories since they start to make associations of benefic effects by the intake of certain foods. Therefore including superfoods and the right nutrient quantities in prepackaged foods as well as communicating so efficiently may add value for the customer.
In these times of unprecedented scrutiny, brands are expected to clearly communicate the practical benefits of their products.

Design as been long associated with gender. Genderless design is interpreted as a design style that breaks stereotypes associated with gender-norms. This may be applied to food mainly in the low-carb/light and healthy categories, that are no longer just a female worry.

With specific tests being more affordable - like genetic tests - diet plans can be more informed and tackle different types of bodies and what works for them.
Some doctors are realizing that they should tackle more prevention, intead of just aliviating the symptoms of sickness. A movement is therefore created to force the entry of more informed nutritional decisions into their prescriptions, taking advantage of foods intead of drugs.

While many consumers are actively making the choice to reduce or avoid certain foods (think anything dairy, gluten, eggs, meat…), a significant lot would happily resume their intake if they could. This represents a great part of the appeal in pro+prebiotics, where you healthily repopulate the gut microbiome and feed it as well, to hopefully lead a non-eventful gut-routine and maybe even ease or eliminate some of your intolerances and sensitivities.
Provide a range of products that ease the health monitoring. A range of services that take advantage of these health monitoring devices such as sleep advising.

Besides providing products with heathy features, communicate these features through the adequate channels. People are eager to learn more about health, so provide information for customers and employees about what is healthy (foods and behaviours) and promote discussions about pros and cons of controversy topics.

Create initiatives for customer and for employees that promote healthy habits such as sports events, or educative workshops about food, postures, or stress management.
While the attention to health as increased, the role of food as an emotional tool has not changed. Therefore by creating alternative indulgences, more healthy, it is allowed a free-guilt consumption.

While the attention to health as increased, the role of food as an emotional tool has not changed. Therefore by creating alternative indulgences, more healthy, it is allowed a free-guilt consumption.  Restaurants like gourmet burger houses and wholewheat pizzas are spreading.

It is now up to companies and institutions to invest in two complementary and necessary venues: transparency so that the person never feels they're being misled and privacy protection methods and structures.

Talk about FREQUENT ONLINE deliveries

app_REWASTEP.label: Reward for each Consumer Journey Step

meta.description: Now that each individual is a continuous data generation machine, people expect a clear benefit for each step of their shopping experience. The ability to convert pain points into perks will be one of the main factors to earn people's preference.

Vlogging has undeniable power, akin to old-timey blogging and their respective influencer community. This is the more organic way of keeping up with friends, celebs or anyone you follow and for a good reason, it is more authentic, personal, human - often even done live for an interactive experience, in essence, a simultaneous conversation with thousands of fans/friends/followers.
Not every entity has the magnitude of Facebook to withstand the loss of trust and finantial hit breach after breach.

One can simply look over to China for cases of this application, but it is easily explained by the shift in the role brick-and-mortar increasingly plays in society: it is no longer the convenient option (that part will be played by e-commerce), people expect to be wowed and to be assisted when going through the effort of going to a physical store. The physical world is needed for knowledgeable advice on a brand's product range and for consumers to get hands-on with what they are looking for in an inspiring setting.

app_CONVCONV.label: As convenient as the most convenient

meta.description: People's expectations are spilling over from one industry to another and between different mediums. Consumers want their visits to the supermarket to be as convenient as their online shopping experiences and their clothing stores to look like a museum.
The tech revolution is shaping the future of work into an unpredictable mix of machine-automated and machine-enhanced tasks.
Develop single dose products in all ranges in food, hygiene and home care. Packaging must be innovative to provide economic and environmental sustainability.
The adoption of cards for payments instead of money has been settled as a rule already. With smartphones being an extension of their owners it makes only sense that payments get digital.

Offering products/services perceived as sophisticated, exquisite or luxurious at an affordable price.
Despite the undeniable persistence and growth of traditional luxury ranges (Rolls Royce sedans, Louis Vuitton handbags or Chateau Petrus bordeaux), we witness today that consumers will seek and purchase luxury in sectors and brands customarily positioned for a completely different target.
Adopt new models to access content. People are quitting classical media and moving towards platforms where they can choose the content they want when they want it.

The senior audience is a very underexplored audience, especially in fields usually developed with younger consumers in mind (think consumer electronics and online marketplaces). There is no shortage of services and tools to leverage access to your offer for a previously underestimated and underapreciated audience.

app_DIFFSTRY.label: Every employee has a different story

meta.description: Every employee has a unique set of needs. Companies should adapt their perks program to address each one of them.
Creating original marketing/storytelling/etc content and products through the use of computer algorithms.

One of the most significant parts contributing to Privacy Protection as a whole, is the preventive avoidance of data leaks, attacks, phishing, fraud, etc... This is the first line of defense, and it should go without saying that consumers only rest assured when they trust this is taken care of. Besides, although it is hard to measure return on investment for prevention, it is certainly cheaper than the PR crises and loss of trust that happens when it fails. Every company today should stop and think if they are prioritizing encryption, VPS usage when relevant, collecting only needed data, and the myriad of other good practices that so many neglect in place of cost reduction or marketing stunts.

An equally important side to transparency is how a brand or company behaves in case of data compromise or any abnormal case of attack. For the most part, what is increasingly being adopted is full transparency, in spite of quiet diffusal. Addressing isues that were not planned for, publicly/semi-publicly, builds trust and meets a more understanding consumer base, as opposed to coming accross as deception and losing valuable client and industry loyalty.
Protecting customers from unauthorized or involuntary access or use of their personal/proprietary data.

Electrical vehicles have been promised as a solution for fighting global warming in mobility since they do not free toxic emissions and the energy can be clean if collected from renewabe sources. It makes only sense that the transport of goods follows the trend, since they account for a great percentage of transportation.

Auto-sustainable houses have in it's conception the design to be as independent as possible and not rely on external sources. Everything is connected in a circular holistic path to reduce waste and increase yields. By applying this concept to stores, sustainability is assured and savings may occur.
Offering products that embrace the inner ambiguities and contradictions of customers' needs and wants.

The proliferation of the Gig Economy is no longer at our doors; it has entered the room completely. The current technological paradigm is allowing companies and job seekers to close the gap between labor supply and demand.

One man's trash is another man's treasure. With the blossom of the Sharing Economy, people are increasingly looking for platforms to let them optimize the lifecycle of their products while getting a benefit from that.
Making itself a part of a story is a powerful strategy for a brand to help its customers relating with its products or services.

Impatiance is growing as consumers keep getting bombed by increasingly amounts of information. Brands have now the responsability to ease that pain by clearly communicating the value proposition of their products in a simple and balanced way.
Adopting solutions and establishing partnerships that supervise the compliance of supply-chain practices with established standards.

Long time coming, but today stronger than ever, alternatives to plastic are highly sought after, seeing as we have not found a reliable method to guarantee correct plastic waste disposal (or its recycling). With harder legislative deadlines being pushed ever so quickly, it is no longer simply good for the planet, it is becoming an operational requirement.

Packaging (and in particular, grocery packaging) is being implemented in parallel to plastic alternatives and should become increasingly relevant with the progression of e-commerce over brick-and-mortar retail. The holy grail in this field is, of course, the grocery bag, which promises to revolutionise the industry as soon as a no-compromise solution comes.

One of the strategies on the war on plastic is to rethink packages, either in size or material composition. Reducing size to only what is necessary and creating materials that are easier to recycle (usually opting in for monomaterials) are tools that should be adopted by both designers and suppliers.
There is a lot of misinformation on sustainability and plastics, so educating customers may be the answer to save the world.

Recycling has been around for at least a decade, however the outputs made with recyclated materials are still scarce. By educating people and improving the separation, recycling may increase it's value, giving birth to new products.

With open borders and the mix of cultures each time more present in a growing number of cities, a need for a comum language and translations arise.
Offering products and services that solve or mitigate nuisances and inconveniences of foreign visitors as well as giving them advantages/benefits  that help make the most of their visits and optimize their experience.

From influencers that show how to live with zero waste to companies that commit to similar goals, garbage is no longer regarded as disposable but as something that is worthwhile taking a second appreciation.
Being unique is the new fashion. Brands should create the conditions for consumers to feel special by customizing their products.

If it's worth a "like", it's worth a visit. The value proposition of a brand is not exclusively inherent to its products or services anymore. The surroundings count.
Design every product and service so that consumers want to take a picture of it and share it.
